instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Troubleshooting
threads.message: So I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board I bought off of eBay with no backlight and its been kinda throwing me for a loop for a little while now. The backlight circuit looks slightly different than previous models with the 1st transistor (at the bottom of the first voltage divider) being integrated with the <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>? At least thats what it looks like... Anyways, the area looked pretty messed up so I went ahead and replaced <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>, both <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7732</RESISTOR> on the feedback trace, and the <DIODE>D7710</DIODE> diode (all visually looked like crap). Still no backlight. I do have 3.3v on the enable pin of <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> however <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> isn't opening because there is 12.56v on pin 4, and also 12.46v on pin 3 (too much) which is why I'm assuming the backlight isn't kicking on. I've confirmed the resistance on both resistors for the first voltage divider and they're giving proper readings.. what am I overlooking?? I'm leaning towards my doner board had a bad <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> chip that I grabbed.. Ideas?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Troubleshooting
threads.message: Are you sure there is an image on the LCD, check with a flashlight. If that is ok check pin 15 and 16 of <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> for continuity to LCD connector.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Troubleshooting
threads.message: Yes I do see the apple logo each time I'm testing it. Very hard angle to test for continuity lol but yes, multimeter did in fact beep between pins 15/16 of the chip and 3/4 of the LCD connector.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Troubleshooting
threads.message:
It's time to check all resistors and traces. First suspects would be:
pin 9 and 10, there should be 0 ohm between if traces are ok
5V to pin 5 and 18
trace between <DIODE>D7710</DIODE> and <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR>
And all the rest if that is ok......

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Troubleshooting
threads.message: Well I did have to repair the trace between <DIODE>D7710</DIODE> and <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR>... but there's also a 2nd problem being that <RESISTOR>R7732</RESISTOR> has continuity to ground on both sides.. Don't have another doner of this model board but I can probably find another resistor if needed.. Or would the chip be shorting it to ground?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Troubleshooting
threads.message: I'd first remove <RESISTOR>R7732</RESISTOR> and check again. If still short it could be short between pin 21 and 22 on <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>, or a dead <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> or even a short in the board.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Troubleshooting
threads.message: With removal of <RESISTOR>R7732</RESISTOR> there is still a short on both pins.. Just gonna order a new <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> and try it out next week.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Troubleshooting
threads.message: Remove <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>, there could be a short in the board!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Troubleshooting
threads.message: Just to post a final update. Another new display driver chip fixed the issue!
